content.intro:
Avant-garde for its music and architecture, Hamburg also reflects its history as the capital of the Hanseatic League (the Hansa), making it a nice surprise at the water's edge.

The city hides its allure—like a pearl in a shell. Not just another grey, seedy port, Hamburg is a bourgeois city with a rebel heart. The second largest city in Germany, it discreetly displays its wealth inside its mansions in the districts of Eppendorf and Blankenese. Life here flows slowly around the Alster lakes and along the mighty Elbe. From the lake to the river, the waves invite contemplation and sports like water-skiing, stand-up paddleboard, and sailing—all right inside the city centre.

The water never sleeps, perhaps because of the tidal range (more than 3.6 metres) on the Elbe, and the city feels the sea deeply. They live together: this is among the largest commercial ports in the world. Integrated into the urban space, port life is a spectacle in and of itself. You only have to see the huge cargo ships cruising up and down the Elbe, each carrying hundreds of containers, as if assembled from giant Lego cubes. To observe them best, take a guided boat tour. One feels infinitely small next to them.

With HafenCity, Hamburg redraws its boundaries and makes the link between the port and the warehouses of Speicherstadt, a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 2015. This new space, once completed, is expected to expand the city centre by 40%. A walk around the Rathaus (city hall) gives a new impression of the city's wealth. The building has 647 rooms (more than Buckingham Palace) and sits on nearly 4,000 wooden piles—a stunning architectural feat in 1886, the date of its construction.

Hamburg definitely has something non-conformist and trend-setting about it. Its music scene reflects this best, almost overshadowing Berlin's. The new Elbphilharmonie, which should open in 2017, constitutes further evidence. But shhh, don't shout too loud! Hamburg is Germany's best-kept secret and holds many surprises, from its unusual converted bunkers to its legendary beaches. ‘Moin moin' Hamburg! In other words, ‘Hi!‘

map.mapTitle: Our selection of must-see places in and around Hamburg

seoData.seoTitle: Travel Guide Hamburg  - Plan your trip to Hamburg with Air France Travel Guide
seoData.seoDescription: Stay in Hamburg: what to visit to Hamburg, where to stay, which restaurant to go? All information to prepare your holidays to Hamburg with Air France.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Hamburg

content.title: Bohemian atmosphere at Sir Nikolai Hotel

introduction.small: Between Hamburg's old town and the modern HafenCity district, Sir Nikolai Hotel strikes a similar dichotomy, with a contemporary design tweak in a traditional house.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bohemian atmosphere at Sir Nikolai Hotel

paragraphs.text:
The Sir Nikolai Hotel took residence in a renovated 19th-century building, typical of Hamburg's Kontorhaus neighbourhood. Facing Nikolaifleet, one of the oldest canals in town, the hotel gives off a bohemian feel with a chic twist. It cultivates a glamourous image through its vintage and arty decoration. The rooms are therefore dressed in warm tones and, presented like small art galleries with contemporary art pieces hung on the walls.
Walk around the corridors, gaze at the high vaulted ceilings and mirror-covered walls, then head to the library: its glass roof is amazing. If every room offers unobstructed views over the city or the canal, the hotel's restaurant's terraces are well worth a stop: in a bistro atmosphere, Izakaya offers fusion food between Japan and Peru with a breathtaking vista over Hamburg. An ideal setting to gulp down a few oysters in wasabi cream served with some Beluga caviar, or a spicy tuna tartare served with crispy rice. A little gem of a hotel, right at the heart of the city.

Sir Nikolai Hotel
Katharinenstraße 29
20457 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 2999 6666

www.sirhotels.com/nikolai

Rooms: from 154 EUR

content.title: The Fontenay, spearhead of modern tourism

introduction.small: In Hamburg, The Fontenay offers high end stays in gorgeous and fascinating setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Fontenay, spearhead of modern tourism

paragraphs.text:
Located on the west bank of the Alster Lake, The Fontenay stands out from the urban landscape with its singular architecture, the curvy structure and fluidity of its lines mirroring the water it faces. Surrounded by a 10,000 sqm park, the hotel reveals unobstructed views that can be enjoyed from every single room's balcony: the lake, the nearby greenery or the city – second largest in Germany – depending on your choice. There, luxury can be felt in every detail, from the large 27-metre high atrium adorned with a huge chandelier to the custom-made furniture adapted to the building's rather original dimensions. The rooms, in which you will find original wooden flooring, showcase a classic style with a resolutely modern touch. Finally, the last floor of the hotel shelters the Lakeside rooftop restaurant, run by starred-Swiss chef Cornelius Speinle. A gigantic spa with infinity pool is also available on the premises, from where you can enjoy unforgettable vistas onto the city. A true gem at the heart of the “German Venice”.

The Fontenay
Fontenay 10
20354 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 6056 6

 www.thefontenay.de/en/

Rooms: from 320 EUR

content.title: At Fardi, travel to the Middle East without ever leaving Hamburg

introduction.small: Syrian cuisine captivates you with its spicy and sweet perfumes in the heart of Hamburg.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: At Fardi, travel to the Middle East without ever leaving Hamburg

paragraphs.text:
Steps away from Alster Lake in Hamburg, the Syrian restaurant Fardi is a flagship of Phoenicia. You will find here all the typical ingredients of the Middle East from chickpeas, to sesame, saffron and cardamom.

Your voyage of savours takes place in a modern, spacious room, where the milk-coloured walls are accented with red brick and where the plates of an immaculate white contrast with their colourful contents.

Fardi offers both a reinterpretation of traditional dishes and nouvelle cuisine. Discover fillet of lamb and basmati rice with feta sauce, rice with cinnamon and aubergine, dates and nuts, or the famous falafel with tahini. Let yourself be impressed by one of the many Syrian or Libyan wines on the menu

Fardi
Hofweg 72
22085 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 360 27440

www.fardi-hamburg.de

Menu: around 55 EUR

content.title: The Gastwerk Hotel, an industrial hotel with ultra-modern decor

introduction.small: In this building from the 1890s, industrial architecture meets modern design, a perfect combination and a great place to sleep for a few nights.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Gastwerk Hotel, an industrial hotel with ultra-modern decor

paragraphs.text:
This red brick building still supplied gas and electricity to the city of Hamburg 150 years ago. Today, designers Regine Schwethelm, Sibylle von Heyden and Armin Fischer have superbly renovated the 8,000 m² and converted it into a hotel.

The brick and steel structure of this industrial building strikes a contrast with the very contemporary decor. Like a huge loft, the interior is bathed in natural light filtering through the glass roof. The 141 rooms and suites are spacious, bright and adorned with warm colours, creating a very welcoming atmosphere.

The Mangold restaurant and L.Bar will allow you to spend a long evening at the hotel, enjoying its unique atmosphere, without setting foot outside. As for the oriental spa at Gastwerk, it takes you away to Morocco for a relaxing moment to reconnect with your body. On the agenda: an Ayurvedic hot-stone massage or foot reflexology.

Gastwerk Hotel Hamburg
Beim Alten Gaswerk 3
22761 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 890 620

www.gastwerk.com/hotels-hamburg/index.php

Rooms: from 92 EUR

content.title: 25hours Hotel Altes Hafenamt: the new port address

introduction.small: Twenty-four hours are not enough to enjoy this beautiful hotel close to the Speicherstadt and the emerging HafenCity district.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 25hours Hotel Altes Hafenamt: the new port address

paragraphs.text:
Having just dropped anchor in the harbour, this brand new hotel is already making waves. Two steps away from sister establishment 25hours Hotel HafenCity, urban nomads sleep here like sea captains, and with good reason: the 1885 building, all in brick, once housed the administrative offices of the port, where sailors met to swap sea yarns.

The 49 cosy, full-comfort rooms are in faded tones and loaded with nice touches: a hot water bottle, a pink world map, and a shopping bag to borrow during your entire stay—just like the bike and the Mini car, free for your use.

Another trip, this time culinary, is to be had in the NENI restaurant, which serves Middle Eastern dishes. A delicious hummus is part of the breakfast, along with all the great classics. The bar, inhabited by a giant portrait of a sailor on the wall, is a popular rendezvous among Hamburgers in the know.

25hours Hotel Hamburg Altes Hafenamt
Osakaallee 12
20457 Hamburg
+49 (0)40 555 5750

www.25hours-hotels.com

Rooms: from 155 EUR

content.title: Mutterland: a fine and funky 100% German deli

introduction.small: A paradise for discerning palates, this shop offers a variety of delicious local products

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mutterland: a fine and funky 100% German deli

paragraphs.text:
In his lumberjack shirt and perfectly trimmed beard, Jan Schawe looks like a young man. His secret? Good food! Almost ten years ago, the designer opened the Mutterland delicatessen—a tribute not to Germany but to his own mother. The shop celebrates national products, 80% of them from Hamburg. His good taste, aesthetics, and humour blend cheerfully on the shelves, where bottles of organic, fair-trade, Hamburg-made “Lemonaid” sit next to others by Schmack Schnick. Further down are jars of Fiete dark-chocolate spread, with a handsome sailor on their labels, alongside pretty pots of Käthe milk chocolate. Sweet or savoury, all these delicacies are bundled up before your eyes in a pretty paper closed with a sewing machine. You can also lunch at Mutterland Stammhaus, near the Central Station (at No. 9 on Ernst-Merck-Straße).

Mutterland City
Poststraße 14-16
20354 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 3500 4360

www.mutterland.de

content.title: Altes Mädchen: an introduction to the world of hop growing

introduction.small: Both bistro and brasserie, this address is a must for all lovers of blond, brown, and white beer. It's also ideal for brunch by the fire or on the patio.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Altes Mädchen: an introduction to the world of hop growing

paragraphs.text:
Where to start? Beer lovers won't know what to choose from the 60 beers on the menu, which come from all around the world with the exception of the Ratsherrn, brewed in the adjoining building. Altes Mädchen (‘old maid' in German) is known for its rigorous selection but it also offers soft drinks and Samova tea (‘Made in Hamburg'). As for the food, the focus is on local specialities and hamburgers designed by Patrick Rüther and Tim Mälzer (the local Jamie Oliver) from the nearby restaurant Bullerei.

The friendly room is warmed by a wood stove in winter, and the patio is lovely. Check out the Craft Beer Store (www.craftbeerstore.de), which offers a variety of beers to go, or grab a coffee in the Elbgold Kaffee (www.elbgold.com) which is also nearby.

Braugasthaus Altes Mädchen
Lagerstraße 28b
20357 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 8000 77750

www.de.altes-maedchen.com

Menu: around 17 EUR

content.title: Fairmont Hotel Vier Jahreszeiten Hamburg: understated luxury

introduction.small: On the shore of the Inner Alster, this elegant hotel is a fixture of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fairmont Hotel Vier Jahreszeiten Hamburg: understated luxury

paragraphs.text:
Hotel Vier Jahreszeiten has a special place in the heart of Hamburg. Opened in 1897, it remained, for nearly a century, in the hands of the Haerlin family, who gradually added new parts to it. Its credo of ‘service, service, service', made it a favourite of the international jet set. Today, the families of local haute bourgeoisie come to dinner on special occasions.

Its 156 rooms and suites are showcases of unostentatious luxury. Antique furniture and thick carpets provide an atmosphere of earlier, more inviting epochs. While preserving tradition, the hotel has ceaselessly renovated. The Restaurant Haerlin's (two Michelin stars) aquarium dining room lets guests watch chef Christoph Rüffer in action. The Grill, in 1920s Art Deco style, serves one of the best Wiener Schnitzels in town. You can also test the tables at Doc Cheng's or the Café Condi.

Fairmont Hotel Vier Jahreszeiten Hamburg
Neuer Jungfernstieg 9-14
20354 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 3494 0

www.fairmont.com

Rooms: from 295 EUR

content.title: Under the cobblestones, the beach

introduction.small: Hambourg réserve bien des surprises. Qui imaginerait des bancs de sable urbains dans cette ville du nord ?

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Under the cobblestones, the beach

paragraphs.text:
The sea may well be 100 kilometres from Hamburg, but beaches are never too far away. Along the Elbe, shorelines of fine sand welcome walkers and a few brave swimmers on sunny days—beware, however, of the tides and currents.

In the charming neighbourhood of Övelgönne, laze on the sand in one of the lounge chairs of the legendary Strandperle bar (or its neighbour, Ahoi Strandkiosk), while watching the to and fro of gigantic freighters. These sea monsters sail to other ports, loaded with too many containers to count. It's a spectacular sight.

The sand tour continues in front of houses once inhabited by sea captains, port pilots, and whalers. The alternative? Head out even further, across the wealthy neighbourhood of Blankenese, and land at Treppenviertel (the ‘district of stairs'), with its pseudo airs of the Riviera, in front of the Airbus assembly plant. You can also board the boat for the St Pauli Piers (April to September).

Strandperle
Övelgönne 60
22605 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 880 1112

www.strandperle-hamburg.de

content.title: Speicherstadt: the Hamburg district newly classified by UNESCO

introduction.small: Surprisingly, Hamburg has more bridges and canals than Amsterdam. Here is just a sample.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Speicherstadt: the Hamburg district newly classified by UNESCO

paragraphs.text:
‘Vertiginous'—this is the word that comes to mind when walking the streets of Speicherstadt (‘City of Warehouses'). Bordering the canals and near the Elbe, the building complex was built between 1885 and 1927. Behind the facades of neo-Gothic and neo-Romanesque brick, coffee and spices were stored along with other goods. In the summer of 2015, the 370,000-square-metre district was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site alongside the nearby Kontorhaus District, built in the 1920s and 1930s. A place of commercial port transactions it was, according to UNESCO, the first business district in Europe. It includes the Chilehaus (the ‘house of Chile'), an architectural curiosity that recalls the prow of a ship. The architect Fritz Höger designed it for the ship owner Henry Sloman, whose fortune came from Chilean saltpetre. Push open one of its doors and have a peak at its fascinating interiors.

Chilehaus
Fischertwiete 2
20095 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 3491 94247

www.chilehaus.de

content.title: Atelier F: French-American cuisine

introduction.small: In the city centre, this address overlooking the canal provides a nice break from shopping.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Atelier F: French-American cuisine

paragraphs.text:
The menu states it aptly: ‘Liberty, equality and damn good food'. The Atelier F joyously hyphenates France and the US in its dishes. In the five rooms, all with different atmospheres, the floor creaks like an old house. The charming bar at the Bistro & Bar is called ‘Le Grand Bordel' (The Big Mess), and the three rooms that run along the canal are as sunshine-filled as a summer patio.

In the last room, decorated in New York industrial style, you can follow the creation of your hamburger behind a glass wall. It is served on a wooden board and accompanied by chips in a mini fryer. The menu also has mussels and ‘frites', salads, pasta, and children's dishes.

Atelier F
Bleichensteg
Große Bleichen 31
20354 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 3501 5215

www.atelierf.eu

Menu: around 14 EUR

content.title: A green and blue city

introduction.small: Hamburg has its feet in the water and its head in the trees. With nearly 3,000 hectares of parks, this is one of the greenest cities in Europe.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A green and blue city

paragraphs.text: What do the good citizens of Hamburg do during their lunch hour? They get in their kayaks or go stand-up paddling on the canals and Alster Lake. At night, they go sailing. In winter, when the lake is frozen (which is increasingly rare), Hamburgers strap on their skates. This blue mirror of 164 hectares is actually two lakes: Außenalster (Outer Alster) and Binnenalster (Inner Alster). Bordered by majestic properties, the lake water splashed up against their gardens until 1953, when the banks became public. Now a nice park, a favourite place for joggers, surrounds the lake. Is that the smell of Currywurst (curried sausage) tickling your nostrils? It's from a barbecue on the park lawn. To feel like a true Hamburger for a few hours, rent a boat and cross the Alster. It's worth it just for the view; the city provides no more exotic experience.

content.title: The museum triangle

introduction.small: Three impressive places offer a nice walk through the history of art of all genres.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The museum triangle

paragraphs.text:
In the three buildings of the Hamburger Kunsthalle, you'll come across art works from medieval times to the modern era, including famous paintings by Gerhard Richter and Neo Rauch in the permanent collection. And then there's the rich calendar of temporary exhibitions.

A few strides away, the Museum für Kunst und Gewerbe (Museum of Arts and Crafts) has beautiful collections of porcelain, furniture, musical instruments, and more. Relocated and reassembled, the former canteen of the newspaper Spiegel, designed by Verner Panton in 1969, is a real curiosity.

Next up is the Deichtorhallen, composed of two structures of steel and iron dating from 1911 to 1913. These old converted market halls have housed contemporary art and photography exhibitions since 1989. Andy Warhol, Martin Kippenberger, Louise Bourgeois, Andreas Gursky, and Stephan Balkenhol are just some of the artists whose works have been exhibited here. Programming is always of the highest calibre, as is the selection of photography books from the bookstore.

Hamburger Kunsthalle
Glockengießerwall 5
20095 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 4281 31200

www.hamburger-kunsthalle.de

Museum für Kunst und Gewerbe Hamburg
Steintorplatz
20099 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 4281 34880

www.mkg-hamburg.de

Deichtorhallen
Halle für Aktuelle Kunst & Haus der Photographie
Deichtorstraße 1-2
20095 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 321 030

www.deichtorhallen.de

content.title: Motel One Hamburg Am Michel: in the heart of the city

introduction.small: Born in Germany, this 'budget design hotel' chain offers good value.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Motel One Hamburg Am Michel: in the heart of the city

paragraphs.text:
The strong point? Its geographical location. At the end of the Reeperbahn, this hotel is close to the neo-Baroque church of St Michael (Sankt Michaelis). The rooms at the Motel One offer perfect comfort for guests in town for business and/or pleasure. It was renovated in late 2015, with a focus on the common areas.

Hamburg is very present in the decor, either through a freighter model on the wall, the wallpaper in the bar paying homage to the port, or in a nod to the underwater life scrolling on TV screens. The 437 rooms are spread over nine floors. Good to know: you have to choose between the view and the quiet. Some rooms—the highest perched—open onto a fragment of the port but are relatively noisy. The other rooms overlook a quiet street.

Hotel Motel One Hamburg Am Michel
Ludwig-Erhard-Straße 26
20459 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 3571 8900

www.motel-one.com

Rooms: from 80 EUR

content.title: Henri Hotel: like spending the night at a friend's

introduction.small: In the heart of downtown, a hotel with a warm and friendly family atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Henri Hotel: like spending the night at a friend's

paragraphs.text:
Henri is the little friend that we like to drop in on. His ‘house' of 65 rooms has the air of a vintage American TV show from the 1950s or 1960s. The reception, in the salon, extends to a bar and kitchen. Serve yourself from the refrigerator at any time of the day or night—just note down the drinks, snacks, and prepared dishes you take on the sheet of paper. Soup simmering on the stove and bunwiches await gourmands (free from 7:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. weekdays).

In this warm and friendly atmosphere, it's hard to go back to one's room. Yet the Henri is decorated with inspiration and humour, with neo-retro furniture, and with wallpaper that mixes old typewriters with smartphone headphones. On leaving, you'll promise to return. After all, Henri is (almost) a family friend.

Henri Hotel
Bugenhagenstraße 21
20095 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 554 357 557

www.henri-hotel.com/

Rooms: from 101 EUR

content.title: HafenCity: the district of the future

introduction.small: Between the shore and the waves, these new streets are shaping the landscape of tomorrow with buildings that look like they are part of a giant Lego set.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: HafenCity: the district of the future

paragraphs.text:
HafenCity is a city within a city. One of Europe's largest urban development projects, built on the banks of the Elbe, this new district extends Speicherstadt and will increase the area of the city centre some 40% by 2025. Buildings seem to be popping up overnight, except perhaps, the Elbphilharmonie, which is definitely taking its time.

No matter: this spectacular achievement by the firm Herzog & de Meuron is a technical and architectural wonder. Placed on the structure of a former cocoa warehouse, its wave-shaped roof is the new symbol of the city. The concert calendar opens in January 2017. All around, other architects have left their signature marks, such as the late Zaha Hadid, who designed the beautiful promenade along the waterfront, and Rem Koolhaas, who designed the Hamburg Science Center. Lovers of beautiful cars should stop in at the Automuseum Prototyp, which displays rare and vintage sports cars.

Elbphilharmonie
Platz der Deutschen Einheit 1
20457 Hamburg
+49 (0)40 3576 6666

www.elbphilharmonie.de

Automuseum Prototyp
Shanghaiallee 7
20457 Hamburg
+49 (0)40 3999 6970

www.prototyp-hamburg.de

content.title: The George: a hotel with a posh British accent

introduction.small: A member of the Design Hotels network, this property moored near the Alster in 2008.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The George: a hotel with a posh British accent

paragraphs.text:
In 2008, a little corner of England landed in the vibrantly multicultural, trendy, and gay friendly St Georg district. At The George, three famous designers (Terence Conran, Kit Kemp, and Paul Smith) interact in unexpected ways through some interesting decorative touches. Chesterfield armchairs and Union Jack cushions evoke the atmosphere of an English private club at teatime.

But these traditional touches are jostled by the beautiful collection of contemporary photographs on the walls, including in one of the two libraries. The 125 rooms and suites (five categories) are decidedly elegant, yet with a twist thanks to the Eames rocking chairs and colourful wallpaper. The bar is famous for its varieties of gin and whiskey, and the DaCaio restaurant is popular with tourists and all of Hamburg, in fact. In summer, the surprise is at the top of the stairs to the roof. The rooftop bar has a stunning view of the lake and its sailboats.

The George Hamburg
Barcastraße 3
22087 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 890 62 428

www.thegeorge-hotel.de

Rooms: from 112 EUR

content.title: Herr Max: a sweet dream

introduction.small: A pastry shop and tearoom a bit rock 'n' roll in the trendy Schanze district.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Herr Max: a sweet dream

paragraphs.text:
The milky-white tiles of this former dairy, built in 1905, are still on the walls, giving one the impression of being inside a wedding cake. A ragtag decor warms the room. Under the counter window, sweet temptations stand guard: apple tart, poppy seed and lemon cake, lemon mango mousse—some recipes are gluten and lactose free—and much more. They disappear in no time but rest assured, the next batch is already on its way.

Meanwhile, sit over coffee. Also ask to see the ‘special orders': pastry chef and confectioner Matthias Max likes to have fun sculpting Nike shoe-shaped cakes or an old Rolleiflex camera, or even a surfer riding a wave. His creativity is delicious!

Herr Max
Schulterblatt 12
20357 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 6921 9951

www.herrmax.de

Menu: from 1.95 EUR

content.title: Clouds: close to paradise

introduction.small: At 105 metres, the highest Hamburg restaurant offers incredible views of the harbour, the old district of Hamburg, and St Pauli.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Clouds: close to paradise

paragraphs.text:
High aloft in the dancing towers (‘Tanzende Türme') of architect Hadi Teherani, Clouds is aptly named, as it rubs right up against them. The elevator to the 23rd floor sets the tone as it passes through a ceiling covered with cumulus. Arriving at your destination, the whole city, or almost all of it, is laid out before you. The Elbphilharmonie sits proudly on the waves and the Reeperbahn, by day, suddenly seems calmer. It's difficult to detach one's eyes from the huge bay windows (ask when you book if it's possible to have a table close to one).

Unable to compete with the view, the decor plays the card of discretion. Broad leatherette chairs are the only original touch. In the room, the aproned servers serve beautiful cuts of meat, the house specialty, as well as cod and spelt risotto, equally tantalizing. In fine weather, the roof patio on the 24th floor is transformed into the Heaven's Nest bar.

Clouds
Reeperbahn 1
20359 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 3099 3280

www.clouds-hamburg.de

Menu: around 30 EUR

content.title: Miniatur Wunderland: the world on another scale

introduction.small: Hamburg under a magnifying glass, or almost... This museum of moving miniatures presents this city in another manner, alongside other destinations, which are sure to also make you dream.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Miniatur Wunderland: the world on another scale

paragraphs.text:
You don't have to be a kid to get excited before these animated miniatures. Visitors here are like Alice in Wonderland, when she ate the cake and began her trip into the unknown. There are snowy Austrian Alps, the sunny Grand Canyon, and the bright lights of Las Vegas. There are also Swiss trains, which always run on time, and a chocolate factory supplying (real) mini-doses.

This little world, teeming with details and humour, is controlled by more than 40 computers. The airport is especially well done: some 40 different aircraft (Cessna to the Airbus A380) land and take off on the runway amid the noise of the turbines. In its Hamburg, HafenCity shows all its secrets, including the Elbphilharmonie—its model gives a good overview of the amazing concert hall. Remember to book in advance: the museum is a huge success.

Miniatur Wunderland Hamburg
Kehrwieder 2-4
Block D
20457 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 300 6800

www.miniatur-wunderland.com

content.title: Schanzenviertel and Karolinenviertel: the city's creative districts

introduction.small: To get a good whiff of the city's artiest air, nothing beats a stroll through these colourful spots.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Schanzenviertel and Karolinenviertel: the city's creative districts

paragraphs.text:
The neighbouring districts of Schanze and Karolinen are best roamed on foot, from one to the other, in order to see how they differ. The first is known for its alternative side, characterised by the Rote Flora, a cultural centre first squatted in 1989 and recently painted burgundy red. The place symbolises resistance to the inevitable gentrification of the neighbourhood—like the hip cafes and patios just opposite on Schulterblatt street. This is the meeting place for young creative types of every stripe. Further on, the Karolinen district remains the home of independent shops. The Marktstraße opens not far from an amazing and huge bunker. At night, this legacy of World War II vibrates to the sounds of the city's best DJs, especially in the club Uebel & Gefährlich. A new project aims to make it less austere by giving it a ‘green' roof—a grand idea. In its shadow, a nice flea market, the Antik- und Flohmarkt ‘Flohschanze', is held every Saturday, from 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.

Uebel & Gefährlich
Feldstraße 66
20359 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 3179 3610

www.uebelundgefaehrlich.com

Antik- und Flohmarkt ‘Flohschanze'
Neuer Kamp 30
20357 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 2702 766

content.title: Closed: the Hamburg fashion address

introduction.small: The city has its own fashion style. To discover it, go to this lovely downtown shop.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Closed: the Hamburg fashion address

paragraphs.text:
Karl Lagerfeld is the best-known Hamburger, but the designer Jil Sander has also registered her eponymous brand internationally. The Schanze district may be the home of the Montblanc pen, but Hamburg is also the place where Closed fashion grew up. Founded in 1978 in Italy and now based in Eppendorf, an upscale neighbourhood with expensive homes, it embodies the local spirit: chic but casual.

The clothes, often coloured, accompany all aspects of local daily life, including the inevitable walk with the dog around the Alster (you rarely see so many canine species in a city). After falling for their jeans for men or women, make a detour to the Galerie Commeter, which presents modern and contemporary art—and has done so since 1821! The gallery had a little sister in 2008, Persiehl & Heine, specialising in photo art, where the photographs of, among others, Sarah Moon have already been shown.

Closed
Bergstraße 11
20095 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 3039 2196

www.closed.com

Galerie Commeter - Persiehl & Heine
Bergstraße 11
20095 Hamburg

+49(0)40 326 321

www.persiehl-heine.de/ceemes/

content.title: Bistro Vienna: the neighbourhood brasserie

introduction.small: Say its name and smiles brighten the faces of Hamburg. This restaurant is a classic that always pleases.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bistro Vienna: the neighbourhood brasserie

paragraphs.text:
One has to take one's time at Bistro Vienna. Enjoy a modest glass of white at the counter, talk to the waiter, converse with your neighbours… The restaurant is very small, so it invites cosy gatherings. The room can only accommodate 30 people at a time, but in summer the Biergarten multiplies your chance of getting a seat. This Hamburg institution does not take bookings. The only way to get a table is to wait patiently at the bar. The warm atmosphere provides a foretaste of Sven Bunge's flavourful cuisine, which is European, not just Austrian, despite the restaurant's name. Still, don't pass up the Wiener Schnitzel, with cucumber salad and potatoes, served on red-and-white chequered tablecloths under mirrors that make the room feel larger. This is a (very) good address in the Eimsbüttel district.

Bistrot Vienna
Fettstraße 2
20357 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 439 9182

www.vienna-hamburg.de

Menu: around 25 EUR

content.title: The sound of Hamburg

introduction.small: Music is in this city's DNA. Hamburg vibrates to the rhythm of electro, folk, pop, punk, and, of course, classical. Overall, it's an astonishing melting pot for the ears.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The sound of Hamburg

paragraphs.text:
Music has always played an important part in the city's popular culture. In 1960, the Beatles gave their first concert here, at the Indra Club. Finding them too amateurish, the club manager added a striptease act. The effervescent Stefanie Hempel has anecdotes like these in spades. For ten years, she has organized unusual tours hat follow in the footsteps of the Fab Four, punctuated by strummed notes on her rock ‘n' roll ukulele.

Music has flowed along the Elbe ever since. The city has some 200 independent music labels. Hanseplatte specialises in the CDs and vinyl of Hamburg groups—of which there are many. The record shops participate in the bubbling music scene; the various pop, folk, rock, and hip-hop rooms are concentrated around the Reeperbahn (Große Freiheit, Molotov, Mojo…). As for classical music, there's the new Elbphilharmonie, which is scheduled to open in 2017 in the HafenCity district.

Hanseplatte
Neuer Kamp 32
20357 Hamburg

+49 (0)40 2857 0193

www.hanseplatte.de

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Hamburg
content.introduction: With its oceanic climate, Hamburg is subject to winds that bring frequent rains. Although cold, winters are milder than in eastern and southern Germany. The summer heat is often tempered by breezes and showers. Spring is the best time to visit the city, as it enjoys more than 600 seasonal hours of sunshine.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in Germany is the Euro (EUR).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Hamburg Helmut-Schmidt International Airport
airports.description:
The Hamburg-Fuhlsbüttel airport is 8.5 kilometres (5 miles) north of the city centre.

The Hamburg Helmut-Schmidt International Airport is located 8.5 kilometres (5 miles) north of the city centre.
  • 2 terminals, linked by free shuttle service
    • T1 (Air France, Level 1)
    • T2

Getting from the airport to Hamburg and back:
  • By car
    • The airport is situated between the R2 and R3 ring roads on the B433 highway. You can reach Hamburg via the A7 motorway. To return to the airport from Hamburg, take exit 23 Schnelsen-Nord from the A7.
    • Six parking facilities are available at the airport: four short and long-term near the terminals, and two further away yet cheaper.
    • Car rental companies are located in Terminal 2.
  • By train:
    The fastest and cheapest way to get downtown is the commuter train or S-Bahn (line 1), which will take you directly to Hamburg Hauptbahnhof, the main station, in 25 minutes. Make sure to board cars at the front of the train (the cars at the back go in a different direction). Departures every 10 minutes, in front of the terminals. Price is EUR 3.30, one way.
  • By bus:
    Several buses connect the airport to the city centre in about 30 minutes: lines 39, 274, 292, 392, 605 and the 606 night bus, which stops at the main railway station. One way: EUR 3.30.
  • By shuttle:
    A free shuttle connects the two terminals every ten minutes.
  • By taxi:
    Taxis are parked in front of each terminal. Allow EUR 25 and 30 minutes for a ride downtown.
  • Services: Shops, bars and restaurants, banks, currency exchange, ATMs, post office (T2), tourist info, casino, access for disabled passengers, children's area (T1), dry-cleaning service, and free internet access (Wi-Fi) in the airport.
  • Telephone: +49 (0)40 507 50
  • Website: www.hamburg-airport.de/en

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Hamburg
transportation.description: Hamburg is fairly spread out but has an extensive and well organised public transport network composed of U-Bahn (underground), S-Bahn (suburban trains), buses, and water buses that run down the Elbe river.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Once you arrive in Hamburg, don't hesitate to get in touch with tourism professionals for information and help in organising your stay.

information.title: Hamburg Tourist Board
information.description:
Offers sightseeing recommendations, tourist information and brochures.

The tourist office has several branches in the city:

The head office is inside Hamburg Hauptbahnhof (Monday to Saturday from 9:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m.; Sundays and holidays from 10:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.)

Another branch is located on the harbour at Landungsbrücken, between pontoons 4 and 5 (Sunday to Wednesday from 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. and Thursday to Saturday from 9:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m.)

The third is at the airport in the Airport Plaza, between terminals 1 and 2 (daily from 6:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m.)

  • Telephone: +49 (0)40 300 51 701
  • Website: www.hamburg-travel.com/

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description:
In order to travel in the best conditions and for your health and safety, we invite you to check all information regarding preventive measures and best practices to be respected, available on the official website of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs: https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/

Your comfort, well-being and health are at the heart of Air France's concerns, and we want to help you prepare for your trip in the best way possible. Find out more about the measures taken to ensure safe travelling on our website: https://www.airfrance.fr/FR/en/common/page_flottante/information/coronavirus.htm#notre-engagement-sanitaire

See your doctor before you travel. It is also recommended to take out insurance covering medical expenses and repatriation before your trip. Hamburg counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic German phrases that will make your stay in Hamburg a little easier:
phrases: Hello / Good morning / Good afternoon: Guten Morgen (morning) / Guten Tag (during the day)
Could you repeat ?: Können Sie bitte wiederholen?
What time is it ?: Wie spät ist es?
How much is (…)?: Wie viel kostet es?
Where can I find (…)?: Wo kann ich (…) finden?
Where can I buy (…)?: Wo kann ich (…) kaufen?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Hamburg
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Hamburg each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: March or April: Good Friday (Karfreitag - national event)
March or April: Easter Monday (Ostermontag -  national holiday)
May 1: Labour Day (Tag der Arbeit -  national holiday)
events.description: On the first of May, it is customary to offer a sprig of lily-of-the-valley to close ones. Many vendors occupy the pavement on that occasion!

events.title: May 5-8: Hamburg Port Anniversary (Hafengeburtstag - local)
events.description: The world's biggest port festival, paying tribute to the city's emblem founded in 1189. The event includes many cultural and historical celebrations on land and water.

events.title: October 3: Day of German Unity (Tag der Deutschen Ein-heit - local)
events.description: On this holiday, the inhabitants of Hamburg commemorate, as elsewhere in the country, the reunification of Germany in 1990. It is the only common state holiday fixed by federal law—all other holidays are governed by regional law.

events.title: December 25: Christmas (Weihnachtstag, national)
events.description: Like the rest of Germany, Hamburg has several traditional Christmas markets during the Christmas season. The atmosphere is especially magical in the historic market at town hall square with, among other events, Santa's sleigh thrice-a-day flyby. Children will enjoy the fairy-tale boats, which sail on the Binnenalster, one of the city's two lakes.

events.title: December 26: Boxing Day (Zweiter Weihnachtsfeiertag – national)
events.description: In Hamburg, December 26 is an officially recognized Christian holiday.

events.title: December 31: New Year's Eve (national)
events.description: The best place to ring in the new year is at the port of Hamburg, which is lit up by a giant fireworks display along the Elbe.

administrativeProcedures.title: TRAVEL REQUIREMENTS FOR FRENCH CITIZENS
administrativeProcedures.description:
It is not necessary to apply for a visa for stays in Germany of less than three months. The Foreign Office (Ausländeramt) will issue you a residence permit (Aufenthaltserlaubnis) on presentation of supporting resources, a certificate of residence (Wohnungsbescheinigung), and a valid ID.

To travel serenely in Hamburg and Germany, follow the travel advice of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs: www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/conseils-par-pays/allemagne

administrativeProcedures.title: TRAVEL REQUIRE-MENTS FOR OTHER COUNTRIES Entry requirements for Germany
administrativeProcedures.description:
Most people visiting Germany do not require a visa and are allowed to stay in the country for 90 days, if they have a valid passport.

To find out if you need to apply for a visa, see this chart. Residents of countries marked with a « no » can enter Germany without a visa and stay for up to 90 days. If you need to apply for your visa or Germany before coming to Germany depends on your country of origin. Please check the exact conditions here. List price for visa is 60 EUR, with some exceptions.

For more information, visit the website of the Office of the German Federal Foreign Office : www.auswaertiges-amt.de/EN/

usefulAddresses.title: German Consulate in France (Consular and Legal Services)

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.title: GOVERNMENT OFFICES
administration.openingHours: Usually open from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday to Thursday. Friday closing time is usually 2:00 p.m.

banks.title: BANKS
banks.openingHours: Usually open from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday to Friday.

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime:
Start of daylight saving time: last Sunday in March

End of daylight saving time: last Sunday in October
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Germany, leaving a tip is recommended and always appreciated. An appropriate tip in this case is anywhere between 5 and 10% of the bill at restaurants or bars. Do not leave the tip on the table, but give it at checkout.
